snippet: At a time of deepening austerity, Britons seem to have turned against their national leaders in bellwether mayoral and local council elections.
abstract: London Mayor Boris Johnson provides a modest lift for the British Conservative Party after winning re-election amid a deluge of defeats for his party in local races; victory establishes Johnson as a potentially serious nuisance, if not credible threat, to Prime Min David Cameron, who has come under attack recently from both the left and the right. Photo (M)

byline.original: By SARAH LYALL; John F. Burns contributed reporting from London, and Alan Cowell from Berlin

lead_paragraph: LONDON -- Boris Johnson, the towheaded, nimble-tongued mayor of London, provided a modest lift for the British Conservative Party on Friday after winning re-election amid a deluge of defeats for the party in local races around the country. Mr. Johnson's slender victory over his nearest challenger, the former Labour mayor Ken Livingstone, was all the more significant because London is a natural Labour stronghold. Indeed, the Conservative deputy mayor, Richard Barnes, lost his own re-election bid to a Labour candidate.

headline.main: London's Mayor Aside, Conservatives Fare Poorly in British Races
